 @font-face {
     font-family: "Roboto-Thin";
     font-weight: 700;
     src: url("//fonts.gstatic.com/s/roboto/v18/3KAd02OzFSDbt78HTOt2og.eot?#iefix");

             <div class="txtNew" data-packed="false" id="WRchTxt1b" style="top:852px;bottom:;left:399px;right:;width:303px;height:auto;position:absolute;margin-left:calc((100% - 980px) * 0.5)">
              <h4 class="font_4" style="line-height:0.9em; font-size:48px;">
               <span class="color_13">
                <span style="font-size:48px;">
                 <span style="line-height:0.9em;">
                  Engage
                 </span>
                </span>
               </span>
              </h4>
              <h2 class="font_2" style="line-height:0.9em; font-size:30px;">
               <span class="color_13">
                with Leaders
               </span>
              </h2>
              <p class="font_8">
              </p>
              <p class="font_9">
               <span class="color_13">
                Leadership Santa Cruz County is a nexus that connects current and future leaders. Participation in the program offers an opportunity to engage with the people, institutions, cultural and social elements of our community.
               </span>
              </p>
             </div>
             <style data-styleid="txtNew" type="text/css">

             <div class="txtNew" data-packed="false" id="WRchTxt1e" style="top:1620px;bottom:;left:400px;right:;width:302px;height:auto;position:absolute;margin-left:calc((100% - 980px) * 0.5)">
              <h3 class="font_3" style="line-height:0.8em; font-size:48px;">
               <span class="color_13">
                <span style="font-size:48px;">
                 Develop
                </span>
               </span>
              </h3>
              <h3 class="font_3" style="line-height:0.8em; font-size:30px;">
               <span style="font-weight:bold;">
                <span class="color_13">
                 <span style="font-size:30px;">
                  Leadership Skills
                 </span>
                </span>
               </span>
              </h3>
              <p class="font_8">
              </p>
              <p class="font_9">
               Assessments and inventories identify your strengths and training sessions develop the skills you need to participate in leadership roles now. Our partnership with the Leadership Challenge training program at Cabrillo College offers an opportunity to follow up and go deeper into developing practices that enable leaders to engage with their teams and constituencies successfully.
              </p>
             </div>
             <style data-styleid="txtNew" type="text/css">
              .txtNew {word-wrap:break-word;text-align:start;pointer-events:none;}

             <div class="txtNew" data-packed="false" id="jfnef0gh" style="top:77px;bottom:;left:393px;right:;width:341px;height:auto;position:absolute;margin-left:calc((100% - 980px) * 0.5)">
              <p class="font_8" style="text-align:center;">
              </p>
              <p class="font_8" style="text-align:center;">
               <span style="font-weight:bold;">
                Registration for Class 34 Open Now!
               </span>
              </p>
              <p class="font_8" style="text-align:center;">
              </p>
              <p class="font_8">
               Leaders in the community who want to better understand Santa Cruz County are encouraged to participate in our 2018/19 program. Topics include education, criminal justice, agriculture, business &amp; tourism, and many others. We will convene one day per month between September and June. You will have the opportunity to visit and learn about places you may never have known existed. New friendships and networking opportunities are a natural outcome of this program. As a graduate you will join over 1,400 alumni who occupy positions of responsibility in business, government, education, and the nonprofit sector. To join this dynamic network of community leaders visit
              </p>
              <p class="font_8" style="text-align:center;">
              </p>
              <p class="font_8" style="text-align:center;">
               <object height="0">
                <a class="auto-generated-link" data-auto-recognition="true" data-content="www.leadershipsantacruzcounty.org" data-type="external" href="http://www.leadershipsantacruzcounty.org" target="_blank">
                 www.leadershipsantacruzcounty.org
                </a>
               </object>
               or call Executive Director,
              </p>
              <p class="font_8" style="text-align:center;">
               Dave Vincent at 831-662-3881.
              </p>
             </div>

&amp; Sustainable Industry Day","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-06-01T21:32:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul>What a way to end the class year!&nbsp;&nbsp;June 1st&nbsp;turned out to be a gorgeous day, great for spending most of it outdoors.&nbsp;&nbsp;The day started at the Marine Sanctuary Exploration Center with a talk and tour by Program Manager, Chelsea Prindle.&nbsp;&nbsp;This was a first-time visit for many in the class.&nbsp;&nbsp;Then John Ricker, County Water Resources Division Director, followed this with a presentation on water issues facing our county.&nbsp;&nbsp;And then class member Amanda Segers talked about her organization, Friend of Santa Cruz State Parks, and how it fits into the picture in terms of being a advocate for our environment.&nbsp;&nbsp;Next the class hopped onto the METRO bus for a tour of the Big Creek and Graniterock properties along the North Coast.&nbsp;&nbsp;Here, they learned how these businesses manage their properties with best management practices so as to have the least impact on the natural resources – especially threatened and endangered species. It was a fun way to end the program with lots of new information about the environment we all enjoy.<\/hatul><hatul>Sponsors:<\/hatul><hatul>Day Sponsor – Big Creek Lumber<\/hatul><hatul>Morning room – The Marine Sanctuary Exploration Center<\/hatul><hatul>Continental Breakfast – Shuttle Captain<\/hatul><hatul>Lunch – Big Creek Lumber<\/hatul><hatul>Transportation:<\/hatul><hatul>Santa Cruz METRO<\/hatul><hatul>Santa Cruz METRO<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"photo","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"f254d5_de55dbbf8fdf4a5e9ed555887ce295cd~mv2_d_3264_2448_s_4_2.jpg","width":3264,"height":2448},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Environment &amp; Sustainable Industry Day","_iid":"5b24320e951c9b17c3200b4f","_hash":"267df68059e11088e8da06c2d5321e22","_createdAt":"2018-06-15T21:39:26.192Z","_updatedAt":"2018-06-15T21:46:00.043Z","permalink":"2018\/06\/01\/Environment-Sustainable-Industry-Day","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[]},"5b15a580e6ac715ab40cbebf":{"_type":"MediaPost","title":"Arts Day","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-05-04T20:47:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul>Santa Cruz County is enriched by the diverse arts community it supports.&nbsp;&nbsp;This message came through loud and clear on Class 33’s Arts Day.&nbsp;&nbsp;The morning began at the MAH with presentations on the value that the arts bring to our community. The class had a chance to hear from Michelle Williams, Executive Director of the Arts Council; Nina Simon, Executive Director of the MAH, and panelists representing various components of the arts community. A walk over to the Civic Auditorium gave the class a chance to learn about the Civic Restoration Project as well as a starting point for a scavenger hunt of public art in downtown Santa Cruz. Then on to the Kuumbwa Center where the class heard what it is like to be an artist as well as enjoy a performance by the Shakti Bhakti dancers. The day ended at the Tannery Arts Center where they heard from the&nbsp;Mayor of Santa Cruz,&nbsp;David&nbsp;Terrazas, and took a tour of the center with Ann Hazels.<\/hatul><hatul>We'd like to thank our many sponsors for today:<\/hatul><hatul>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/hatul><hatul>Facilities:<\/hatul><hatul>Museum of Art &amp; The sun was shining brightly, flowers were blooming, and the bees were buzzing. The class began at the Agriculture History Museum with presentations from the Agricultural Commissioner and his Deputy and another about a sister program called Agri-Culture. Agriculture History Project CEO, John Kegebein, provided a quick tour of the museum and grounds. Then the class boarded the Metro bus and toured California Pajarosa where they learned the art and science of hydroponic rose growing. Next they enjoyed lunch at Gizdich Ranch and learned firsthand about its history from Nita Gizditch (Class 13).&nbsp;&nbsp;From there they headed to Live Earth Farms to learn about Community-Supported Agriculture (CSA).&nbsp;&nbsp;And the day ended with a stop at the Martinelli’s Company Store. Director of Marketing and Sales, Tony Robinson shared insights about the company’s history while the class sampled several varieties of wonderful apple juice. It was a great day with a lot of learning about this important industry in our community.<\/span><\/hatul><hatul><span >Sponsors:<\/span><\/hatul><hatul><span >Day Sponsor – Driscoll’s, in the end, but there was one pretty big surprise.&nbsp; As I was setting everything up I received a call around 7:45am from Maureen McCarty’s, Mark Stone’s District Director, sharing the unfortunate news that Mark would not be able to speak. Turns out he had the same ailment as many other throughout Santa Cruz County.&nbsp; Maureen immediately offered to find a replacement.&nbsp; I thought what were the chances and was reviving my “song-and-dance” routine.&nbsp; I informed the class of the situation and then we were off to our usual start.&nbsp; Scotts Valley City Manager, Jenny Harayama started things with a comprehensive overview of city&nbsp;government&nbsp;primarily thru the lens of the City Mgr.&nbsp; Carlos Palacios, CAO for the County of Santa Cruz followed this with a discussion of County&nbsp;government&nbsp;and his vision for the future.&nbsp; Now Mark Stone’s time!&nbsp; Lo and behold Maureen was able to find John Laird working from home and asked him to cover for Mark.&nbsp; He agreed and the&nbsp;day&nbsp;went on as if nothing unusual had occurred.&nbsp; What are the chances of that!&nbsp;<\/span><\/hatul><hatul><span >After lunch, the class moved over to the Scotts Valley Public Library and received a presentation from Library Director, Susan Nemitz and a brief tour.&nbsp; Then off to the County Jail for a profound and sobering experience as we toured the jail. At the Roundtree Correctional Facility the class learned about the concerted effort being made to rehabilitate inmates who are housed here and of the future plans for this facility. The day ended with a tour of the&nbsp;Watsonville Court House, a welcome by Judge Almquist, and presentations by the Chief Deputy DA, Rob Wade, Public Defender Larry Biggam, and Probation Chief Fernando Geraldo, rounding out an exceptional day of learning about the great things going on in the criminal justice system throughout the county. &amp; Tourism Day","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2016-12-02T21:28:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul>Class 32 couldn't ask for a better day for their session on Business &amp; Tourism. The weather was beautiful, the setting at the&nbsp;Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk&nbsp;was superb, and the presentations were thought-provoking. The day started with a welcome from the Boardwalk's Director of Community Relations, Kris Reyes and from the Day's Sponsor, Beth Carr, CEO of the Santa Cruz Community Credit Union. This was followed by a discussion on transportation lead by RTC's&nbsp;Deputy Director, Luis Mendez and class member Ginger Dykaar.&nbsp;Teresa Thomae&nbsp;followed this with a presentation highlighting the small business landscape within the county. The class then broke into groups with visits to&nbsp;Assembly,&nbsp;NextSpace Santa Cruz,&nbsp;Erik's DeliCafe, and&nbsp;Cruzio Internet. After lunch the class had a chance to hear from Maggie Ivy, CEO of&nbsp;Visit Santa Cruz, and a very interesting talk on the Boardwalk combining its history and leaders by Ted Whiting, Vice President of General Services for the Santa Cruz Seaside Company. The highlight of the day came when&nbsp;Sondra Woods, Advertising Director for the Boardwalk gave a wonderful behind-the-scenes tour of the amusement park. The day turned out to be a memorable experience for all. The day started at the&nbsp;Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary Exploration Center Santa Cruz&nbsp;with a talk about the sanctuary and a tour of the museum. This was followed by presentation on water, and climate change issues facing Santa Cruz County. By mid-morning the class boarded a&nbsp;Santa Cruz Metro&nbsp;bus and headed up the coast. The first stop was&nbsp;Big Creek Lumber&nbsp;who hosted a picnic lunch and then shared their story about how they harvest in a sustainable way. Next the class visited&nbsp;Laguna Creek Beach&nbsp;and were told why Santa Cruz County is considered such a biological \"hot spot.\" The day ended at&nbsp;Graniterock&nbsp;where they were met by the Branch Manager, an environment specialist, a biologist, and an ecologist to hear about the successful protection of the endangered red-legged frog and other endemic species. It turned out to be a very fun day combined with considerable exposure to the natural resources within our community. The day began at the&nbsp;Santa Cruz Police Officers' Association&nbsp;briefing room with presentations by First Alarm's, David Hood (the Day Sponsor), Sheriff Hart, SCPD Chief Vogel, and Dennis Kidd, General Manager of Regional SC 911. The class was then transported to the County Jail for a very sobering tour of this facility. Lunch was served to the class at the Roundtree Lane Men's medium security facility where the differences in detention were explained. Then on to the&nbsp;Watsonville Court House&nbsp;where the class was welcomed by Commissioner Baskett and provided a brief tour the various departments. The day ended with a shared discussion by the District Attorney, Jeff Rosell, the Public Defender, Larry Biggam, and Probation Chief Fernando Giraldo. The class came away with a better understanding of how the criminal justice system is working to reduce recitivism, and a deeper appreciation of what is being done to keep our community safe.<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"photo","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"65c017_654d7e2a4f0245dd8a6bb5587390f228~mv2.jpg","width":960,"height":640},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Criminal Justice Day","_iid":"58b87325f21c551dc691c4a3","_hash":"79a950acb38cd8852727fcb0e99d7126","_createdAt":"2018-01-11T23:41:17.818Z","_updatedAt":"2018-01-11T23:41:17.818Z","permalink":"2017\/03\/02\/Criminal-Justice-Day","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[]},"56f054c10cf26be41bd664f2":{"_type":"MediaPost","title":"Education Day","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2016-02-05T21:37:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul ><span ><span style=\"font-weight:bold;\">Education&nbsp;Day<\/span> was sponsored by the <\/span><span style=\"text-decoration:underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia2522\"><span >Santa Cruz Office of Education<\/span><\/a><\/span><span > and <\/span><span style=\"text-decoration:underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia1yhq\"><span >Graniterock<\/span><\/a><\/span><span >. Sustainable Industry Day","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-06-01T21:32:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul>What a way to end the class year!&nbsp;&nbsp;June 1st&nbsp;turned out to be a gorgeous day, great for spending most of it outdoors.&nbsp;&nbsp;The day started at the Marine Sanctuary Exploration Center with a talk and tour by Program Manager, Chelsea Prindle.&nbsp;&nbsp;This was a first-time visit for many in the class.&nbsp;&nbsp;Then John Ricker, County Water Resources Division Director, followed this with a presentation on water issues facing our county.&nbsp;&nbsp;And then class member Amanda Segers talked about her organization, Friend of Santa Cruz State Parks, and how it fits into the picture in terms of being a advocate for our environment.&nbsp;&nbsp;Next the class hopped onto the METRO bus for a tour of the Big Creek and Graniterock properties along the North Coast.&nbsp;&nbsp;Here, they learned how these businesses manage their properties with best management practices so as to have the least impact on the natural resources – especially threatened and endangered species. It was a fun way to end the program with lots of new information about the environment we all enjoy.<\/hatul><hatul>Sponsors:<\/hatul><hatul>Day Sponsor – Big Creek Lumber<\/hatul><hatul>Morning room – The Marine Sanctuary Exploration Center<\/hatul><hatul>Continental Breakfast – Shuttle Captain<\/hatul><hatul>Lunch – Big Creek Lumber<\/hatul><hatul>Transportation:<\/hatul><hatul>Santa Cruz METRO<\/hatul><hatul>Santa Cruz METRO<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"photo","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"f254d5_de55dbbf8fdf4a5e9ed555887ce295cd~mv2_d_3264_2448_s_4_2.jpg","width":3264,"height":2448},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Environment &amp; Sustainable Industry Day","_iid":"5b24320e951c9b17c3200b4f","_hash":"267df68059e11088e8da06c2d5321e22","_createdAt":"2018-06-15T21:39:26.192Z","_updatedAt":"2018-06-15T21:46:00.043Z","permalink":"2018\/06\/01\/Environment-Sustainable-Industry-Day","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[],"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"f254d5_de55dbbf8fdf4a5e9ed555887ce295cd~mv2_d_3264_2448_s_4_2.jpg","width":3264,"height":2448},"httpsOnPublish":false},"5b15a580e6ac715ab40cbebf":{"_type":"PhotoPost","title":"Arts Day","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2018-05-04T20:47:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul>Santa Cruz County is enriched by the diverse arts community it supports.&nbsp;&nbsp;This message came through loud and clear on Class 33’s Arts Day.&nbsp;&nbsp;The morning began at the MAH with presentations on the value that the arts bring to our community. The class had a chance to hear from Michelle Williams, Executive Director of the Arts Council; Nina Simon, Executive Director of the MAH, and panelists representing various components of the arts community. A walk over to the Civic Auditorium gave the class a chance to learn about the Civic Restoration Project as well as a starting point for a scavenger hunt of public art in downtown Santa Cruz. Then on to the Kuumbwa Center where the class heard what it is like to be an artist as well as enjoy a performance by the Shakti Bhakti dancers. The day ended at the Tannery Arts Center where they heard from the&nbsp;Mayor of Santa Cruz,&nbsp;David&nbsp;Terrazas, and took a tour of the center with Ann Hazels.<\/hatul><hatul>We'd like to thank our many sponsors for today:<\/hatul><hatul>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/hatul><hatul>Facilities:<\/hatul><hatul>Museum of Art &amp; The sun was shining brightly, flowers were blooming, and the bees were buzzing. The class began at the Agriculture History Museum with presentations from the Agricultural Commissioner and his Deputy and another about a sister program called Agri-Culture. Agriculture History Project CEO, John Kegebein, provided a quick tour of the museum and grounds. Then the class boarded the Metro bus and toured California Pajarosa where they learned the art and science of hydroponic rose growing. Next they enjoyed lunch at Gizdich Ranch and learned firsthand about its history from Nita Gizditch (Class 13).&nbsp;&nbsp;From there they headed to Live Earth Farms to learn about Community-Supported Agriculture (CSA).&nbsp;&nbsp;And the day ended with a stop at the Martinelli’s Company Store. Director of Marketing and Sales, Tony Robinson shared insights about the company’s history while the class sampled several varieties of wonderful apple juice. It was a great day with a lot of learning about this important industry in our community.<\/span><\/hatul><hatul><span >Sponsors:<\/span><\/hatul><hatul><span >Day Sponsor – Driscoll’s, beautiful day in many respects.&nbsp;&nbsp;The day started at the Pajaro Dunes which was a venue that many in the class had never seen before.&nbsp;&nbsp;Shaz Roth, both the CEO for the Pajaro Valley Chamber and LSCC Board member, provided a broad overview of the many attributes of the Pajaro Valley.&nbsp;&nbsp;This was followed by a presentation by Shanna Crigger on Graniterock as an example of a very successful business in this part of the county.&nbsp;&nbsp;City Manager, Charles Montoya and Assistant City Manager, Matt Huffacker shared their vision for the City of Watsonville.&nbsp;&nbsp;And finally, Brian Lockwood talked about the challenges and opportunities faced by the Pajaro Valley Water Management Agency.&nbsp;&nbsp;Then onto the METRO bus for a tour of the Watsonville Municipal Airport, lunch at the Agricultural Museum, a tour of the Watsonville Wetlands, and ending at the Water Resources Center adjacent to the Pajaro River.&nbsp;&nbsp;<span in the end, but there was one pretty big surprise.&nbsp; As I was setting everything up I received a call around 7:45am from Maureen McCarty’s, Mark Stone’s District Director, sharing the unfortunate news that Mark would not be able to speak. Turns out he had the same ailment as many other throughout Santa Cruz County.&nbsp; Maureen immediately offered to find a replacement.&nbsp; I thought what were the chances and was reviving my “song-and-dance” routine.&nbsp; I informed the class of the situation and then we were off to our usual start.&nbsp; Scotts Valley City Manager, Jenny Harayama started things with a comprehensive overview of city&nbsp;government&nbsp;primarily thru the lens of the City Mgr.&nbsp; Carlos Palacios, CAO for the County of Santa Cruz followed this with a discussion of County&nbsp;government&nbsp;and his vision for the future.&nbsp; Now Mark Stone’s time!&nbsp; Lo and behold Maureen was able to find John Laird working from home and asked him to cover for Mark.&nbsp; He agreed and the&nbsp;day&nbsp;went on as if nothing unusual had occurred.&nbsp; What are the chances of that!&nbsp;<\/span><\/hatul><hatul><span >After lunch, the class moved over to the Scotts Valley Public Library and received a presentation from Library Director, Susan Nemitz and a brief tour.&nbsp; Then off to the County Jail for a profound and sobering experience as we toured the jail. At the Roundtree Correctional Facility the class learned about the concerted effort being made to rehabilitate inmates who are housed here and of the future plans for this facility. The day ended with a tour of the&nbsp;Watsonville Court House, a welcome by Judge Almquist, and presentations by the Chief Deputy DA, Rob Wade, Public Defender Larry Biggam, and Probation Chief Fernando Geraldo, rounding out an exceptional day of learning about the great things going on in the criminal justice system throughout the county. Tourism. The weather was beautiful, the setting at the&nbsp;Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk&nbsp;was superb, and the presentations were thought-provoking. The day started with a welcome from the Boardwalk's Director of Community Relations, Kris Reyes and from the Day's Sponsor, Beth Carr, CEO of the Santa Cruz Community Credit Union. This was followed by a discussion on transportation lead by RTC's&nbsp;Deputy Director, Luis Mendez and class member Ginger Dykaar.&nbsp;Teresa Thomae&nbsp;followed this with a presentation highlighting the small business landscape within the county. The class then broke into groups with visits to&nbsp;Assembly,&nbsp;NextSpace Santa Cruz,&nbsp;Erik's DeliCafe, and&nbsp;Cruzio Internet. After lunch the class had a chance to hear from Maggie Ivy, CEO of&nbsp;Visit Santa Cruz, and a very interesting talk on the Boardwalk combining its history and leaders by Ted Whiting, Vice President of General Services for the Santa Cruz Seaside Company. The highlight of the day came when&nbsp;Sondra Woods, Advertising Director for the Boardwalk gave a wonderful behind-the-scenes tour of the amusement park. The day turned out to be a memorable experience for all. The day started at the&nbsp;Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary Exploration Center Santa Cruz&nbsp;with a talk about the sanctuary and a tour of the museum. This was followed by presentation on water, and climate change issues facing Santa Cruz County. By mid-morning the class boarded a&nbsp;Santa Cruz Metro&nbsp;bus and headed up the coast. The first stop was&nbsp;Big Creek Lumber&nbsp;who hosted a picnic lunch and then shared their story about how they harvest in a sustainable way. Next the class visited&nbsp;Laguna Creek Beach&nbsp;and were told why Santa Cruz County is considered such a biological \"hot spot.\" The day ended at&nbsp;Graniterock&nbsp;where they were met by the Branch Manager, an environment specialist, a biologist, and an ecologist to hear about the successful protection of the endangered red-legged frog and other endemic species. It turned out to be a very fun day combined with considerable exposure to the natural resources within our community. They met both the new Agriculture Commissioner, Juan Hidalgo and the recently retired Ag Commissioner Mary Lou Nicoletti. They learned about the extent and diversity of agriculture in the county and its significant economic value. They were also introduced to Focus Agri-Culture. Most of the remainder of the day was spent visiting various agricultural sites. They were able to tour&nbsp;California Pajarosa,&nbsp;Live Earth Farm, and&nbsp;Driscoll's&nbsp;Rancho Corralitas. Perhaps the highlight was a visit to&nbsp;Gizdich Ranch&nbsp;for lunch and, of course, some pie a la mode. While enjoying this Nita Gizdich talked about her family story on the ranch. Shaz Roth, ED for the&nbsp;Pajaro Valley Chamber, started things off with a wonderful overview of the valley. Rose Ann Woolpert followed this illustrating how the values of a local business,&nbsp;Granite Rock, reflects and contributes to the quality of life of the community. She touched upon the&nbsp;Algebra Academy&nbsp;and some of the children's books she has published. The class then had an opportunity to meet and ask questions of the new City Manager, Charles Montoya. A&nbsp;Santa Cruz METRO Transit District&nbsp;bus then transported the class to the&nbsp;Watsonville Municipal Airport&nbsp;for a tour, lunch at&nbsp;Ella's at the Airport, and a historical perspective of the valley by Chuck Allen. The day began at the&nbsp;Santa Cruz Police Officers' Association&nbsp;briefing room with presentations by First Alarm's, David Hood (the Day Sponsor), Sheriff Hart, SCPD Chief Vogel, and Dennis Kidd, General Manager of Regional SC 911. The class was then transported to the County Jail for a very sobering tour of this facility. Lunch was served to the class at the Roundtree Lane Men's medium security facility where the differences in detention were explained. Then on to the&nbsp;Watsonville Court House&nbsp;where the class was welcomed by Commissioner Baskett and provided a brief tour the various departments. The day ended with a shared discussion by the District Attorney, Jeff Rosell, the Public Defender, Larry Biggam, and Probation Chief Fernando Giraldo. The class came away with a better understanding of how the criminal justice system is working to reduce recitivism, and a deeper appreciation of what is being done to keep our community safe.<\/hatul>","links":[],"version":3},"coverImageData":{"_type":"CoverImageData","coverImageType":"photo","video":{"_type":"wix:Video","videoId":"","videoType":"","thumbnail":""},"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"65c017_654d7e2a4f0245dd8a6bb5587390f228~mv2.jpg","width":960,"height":640},"isHD":false,"isHeroImage":false},"description":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"","links":[],"version":1},"mobileTitle":"Criminal Justice Day","_iid":"58b87325f21c551dc691c4a3","_hash":"79a950acb38cd8852727fcb0e99d7126","_createdAt":"2018-01-11T23:41:17.818Z","_updatedAt":"2018-01-11T23:41:17.818Z","permalink":"2017\/03\/02\/Criminal-Justice-Day","permalinkVersion":"2","defaultPost":false,"author":"","categories":[],"photo":{"_type":"wix:Image","title":"","src":"65c017_654d7e2a4f0245dd8a6bb5587390f228~mv2.jpg","width":960,"height":640},"httpsOnPublish":false},"56f054c10cf26be41bd664f2":{"_type":"PhotoPost","title":"Education Day","date":{"_type":"wix:Date","iso":"2016-02-05T21:37:00.000Z"},"text":{"_type":"wix:RichText","text":"<hatul ><span ><span style=\"font-weight:bold;\">Education&nbsp;Day<\/span> was sponsored by the <\/span><span style=\"text-decoration:underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia2522\"><span >Santa Cruz Office of Education<\/span><\/a><\/span><span > and <\/span><span style=\"text-decoration:underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMedia1yhq\"><span >Graniterock<\/span><\/a><\/span><span >. <\/span><span style=\"text-decoration:underline;\"><a dataquery=\"#txtMediarc8\"><span >Scotts Valley Civic Center<\/span><\/a><\/span><span >.
